title: Super typhoon three times bigger than previous killer set to smash into Japan
text:
Super typhoon Hagibis had winds gusting up to 168 mph this morning (Picture: AP)

Japan is braced for a super typhoon that is on track to cause widespread destruction with torrential rains and strong winds when it hits this weekend.

Typhoon Hagibis, which is currently roaring over the Pacific ocean, is three times bigger in terms of magnitude than the one which caused three deaths and massive disruption across the greater Tokyo area early last month.

Hagibis, which means speed in Filipino, had sustained winds of up to 168 miles per hour today near Chichi island in the Pacific, about 620 miles off Tokyo’s southern coast.

It was moving north at a speed of 12mph and is expected to weaken over cooler waters as it nears Japan’s main island but is currently the equivalent of a Category 5 hurricane.

The Japan Meteorological Agency said the typhoon is forecast to hit ashore in the Tokyo area late on Saturday and urged people to take precautions to avoid potentially life-threatening danger.

Japan’s central Pacific coast may see torrential rains beginning on Friday while high waves and tides may cause flooding, authorities have warned.

A fallen utility pole downed by winds caused by Typhoon Faxai in Kamakura, outisde Tokyo, in September (Picture: AFP)

The approaching typhoon is spreading fear, especially in Chiba, near Tokyo, which was hit by Typhoon Faxai last month and where many residents are still recovering from damage to their homes.

The typhoon tore down many electrical poles and snapped cables, triggering extensive outages that lasted for weeks, contributing to heat illnesses and other health problems among elderly people.

Three people died as a result and power was cut to 900,000 homes across Tokyo.

Airlines and train services anticipate cancellations this weekend affecting people gearing up for a holiday three-day weekend when a number of sporting events are scheduled.

The typhoon has already caused the cancellation of two Rugby World Cup matches that were to be played on Saturday, including the England-France match planned in Yokohama, near Tokyo.

At the moment, a critical meeting between Scotland and Japan, which is also being staged in Yokohama, is still planned to go ahead, but if it is cancelled Scotland will be automatically eliminated.

Houses damaged by a collapse of the perimeter netting of a golf training field due to strong winds of Typhoon Faxai (Picture: Reuters)

Sheet-covered roofs of houses damaged by Typhoon Faxai in Kyonan, near Tokyo, ahead of another typhoon this weekend (Picture: AP)

Organisers also cancelled a marathon in Sendai and other northern coastal towns, and Formula One racing in Suzuka in central Japan may also be affected.

Chief cabinet secretary Yoshihide Suga said the government will do the utmost for people’s safety and urged residents near the typhoon route to take precautions early.

Free sandbags to shield against flooding have been handed out to people in the city and residents have been urged to make sure they have enough food, water and phones battery should power go down.

In Chofu in Tokyo’s western suburbs, workers at the city hall renovation site reinforced scaffolding and placed protective nets to prevent equipment and construction materials from being blown off.

At a winery in Yamanashi, north of Tokyo, workers picked grapes to save them from the typhoon, Japan’s NHK television said.
